# Unequal Enforcement: The Geography of Non-Violent Arrests in NYC

The New York Police Department (NYPD) arrests thousands of individuals each year. But who gets arrested ‚Äî and for what ‚Äî tells a deeper story than crime statistics alone. Our investigation into arrest data and unemployment rates across New York City reveals a troubling relationship: **Black and Hispanic residents in economically disadvantaged boroughs face a disproportionate number of non-violent arrests**.

---

## Race and Arrests: A Disproportionate Burden

```{r fig-race-offense-borough, echo=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)

df <- read_rds("dataset/combined_nypd_acs_with_coords_fixed.rds")


df <- df %>%
  rename(Borough = borough, Offense = ofns_desc, Race = perp_race) %>%
  filter(!is.na(Borough), !is.na(Offense), !is.na(Race))


top_offenses <- df %>%
  count(Borough, Offense, sort = TRUE) %>%
  group_by(Borough) %>%
  slice_max(n, n = 5) %>%
  pull(Offense)


filtered <- df %>% filter(Offense %in% top_offenses)

plot_data <- filtered %>%
  group_by(Borough, Offense, Race) %>%
  summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%
  group_by(Borough, Offense) %>%
  mutate(proportion = count / sum(count))

ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = Offense, y = proportion, fill = Race)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  facet_wrap(~Borough, scales = "free_x") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 30, hjust = 1, size = 8)) +
  labs(
    x = "Top 5 Offense Types (per Borough)",
    y = "Proportion",
    title = "Distribution of Top Offense Types by Race and Borough",
    fill = "Race"
  )

```

Black and Hispanic individuals make up a disproportionately high share of arrests for the most common non-violent offenses across all five boroughs of New York City. This is especially visible in the Bronx, Brooklyn, and Queens, where offenses like misdemeanor assault, vehicle violations, and miscellaneous offenses show clear racial disparities.

These patterns are not reflective of crime severity, but rather of enforcement practices. The fact that the same types of offenses are consistently associated with higher arrest proportions for Black and Hispanic populations suggests a systemic pattern of targeted policing. This reinforces the broader concern that communities of color are more heavily surveilled ‚Äî and more harshly penalized ‚Äî for low-level offenses.

## Does Economics Play a Role?

```{r fig-unemployment-nonviolent, echo=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)


df <- read_rds("dataset/combined_nypd_acs_with_coords_fixed.rds")


df <- df %>%
  rename(AgeGroup = age_group, Offense = ofns_desc) %>%
  filter(!is.na(AgeGroup), !is.na(Offense))


top_offenses <- df %>%
  count(Offense, sort = TRUE) %>%
  slice_max(n, n = 5) %>%
  pull(Offense)


filtered <- df %>% filter(Offense %in% top_offenses)


plot_data <- filtered %>%
  group_by(Offense, AgeGroup) %>%
  summarise(count = n(), .groups = "drop") %>%
  group_by(Offense) %>%
  mutate(prop = count / sum(count))


ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = Offense, y = prop, fill = AgeGroup)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  theme_minimal() +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 30, hjust = 1, size = 9)) +
  labs(
    title = "Age Distribution Across Top 5 Offense Types",
    x = "Offense Type",
    y = "Proportion",
    fill = "Age Group"
  )

```

Arrests for the most common offenses ‚Äî including petit larceny, felony assault, and drug-related charges ‚Äî are heavily concentrated among individuals aged 25‚Äì44. This age group consistently dominates the arrest proportions across all five offense types. The 18‚Äì24 and 45‚Äì64 brackets also show notable presence, while individuals under 18 and over 65 make up only a small share.

This pattern may reflect broader socioeconomic dynamics: younger adults are often more exposed to environments where petty crimes or drug-related activities are policed more aggressively. The data suggest that policing practices disproportionately affect people in early adulthood, raising concerns about the long-term impacts of criminal records on employment, housing, and community integration.

These findings underscore the importance of age-sensitive approaches to justice. Rather than relying on punitive systems, community-driven and rehabilitative responses may offer more effective and equitable outcomes ‚Äî especially for non-violent offenses committed by younger individuals.

## Conclusion: Systemic Inequality in Plain Sight

Our project reveals how arrests in NYC disproportionately impact Black, Hispanic, and younger individuals ‚Äî especially for non-violent offenses. These patterns highlight concerns about over-policing and demographic bias in certain neighborhoods. By exploring this data interactively, we hope to promote transparency and spark informed public conversation.
